messageBody:
Hi David, hi Johannes

after fooling around with some JUnit and ClasspathSuite (thanks
Johannes) I implemented my own Suite. I just thought there might be a
more standard way to use filters.

Thanks for your replies.

Matthias
----
My implementation:
A CategorySuite that filters all TestSuites containing the appropriate
category.

A Suite with just Unit-Tests would be:
@RunCategory("unit")
@SuiteClasses( { MyTest.class })
@RunWith(CategorySuite.class)
public class UnitTests {
}

The CategorySuite extends Suite from Junit:
public class CategorySuite extends Suite {

@Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
@Target(ElementType.TYPE)
public @interface RunCategory {

/** The category name. */
String value();
}

/**
* Internal use only.
*/
public CategorySuite(Class<?> klass) throws InitializationError {
super(klass);

try {
filter(new CategoryFilter(getCategory(klass)));
} catch (NoTestsRemainException e) {
//No Test? No Filter.
}
}

private static String getCategory(Class<?> klass) throws
InitializationError {
RunCategory category = klass.getAnnotation(RunCategory.class);
if (category == null)
throw new InitializationError(String.format("class '%s'
must have a RunCategory annotation",
klass.getName()));
return category.value();
}
}
